captions.text:
What we have here is the new Ford
Mustang.

It looks ready for the twenty first
century

with its modern fascie and tighter lines but
what's more interesting than the design
is that for the first time in 30 years

this one's turbocharged and it's a four
cylinder. Before you call that last for
me

consider that this Ecoboost makes
10 horsepower and forty
helm feet more than the V-6 and it weighs
quite a bit less than the GT.

The Mustang EcoBoost certainly isn't the
most powerful Mustang lineup but it might
be the most interesting.
Why? Well because what's under here.

That's a turbocharged 2.3 liter inline 4 now
displacement is coincidentally the same
as the turbo SVO from

'84 or '85 although this engine shares
nothing with that engine

it is just an interesting coincidence.
Now when you don't have a V6 or a V8
all those engines are optional

you have a lot of space in the engine
bay and so this 4 cylinder

makes up for that space by adding a turbo.
Starting with the bottom end

it's built you have forged crankshaft, forged
connecting rods,
you have oil squirting piston cooling jets. You have

direct injection so there's delivering
quite a bit of fuel to the engine as well

the turbocharger is a twin-scroll unit
that means

each exhaust port is essentially
delivering two pulses.

There's a low RPM side and a higher RPM
side roughly

and that's what's going to help this
engine get to boost quick,

help reduce lag, or eliminate it
completely.

We'll find out how effective this system
is on the dyno.

We have some good news and some not
particularly good news

standing underneath this particular
Mustang: the not so great news

is that we have the six-speed automatic
transmission instead of the six-speed
manual.

Not the end of the world this automatic
is fine I would have loved to driven this car

with a manual transmission. Anyway the
good news this car has a performance
package

that adds a bunch of different upgrades to
the chassis to help it go faster,

stop better, turn better, and on and on
starting with

the tires and wheels. The wheels are
nineteen by nine inches at all four corners.
On the tires are 2540 Pirelli P-Zeros. We have upgraded brakes on all four corners
to on the front 13.9 inch rotors

with four-piston calipers they're single
piston calipers in the back.

Speaking of the back heading back there
the exhaust pipe

is actually pretty good diameter
coming down the cat although it does shrink up
considerably

the further back we go. We also have one
exhaust pipe
that splits into two because reasons seems to me like you're just

adding weight for styling I'd much
rather have just one exhaust pipe and

save whatever weight you added by doing
that.
Further back we have a 355 rear-end
and

the big story which is what Ford has
been flirting around with

for a long time now: an independent rear
suspension.

Finally Ford has embraced modern
suspension technology

and thrown away the solid rear axle in
favor of some actual sophistication.

And whatever we lose on the drag strip
by losing the solid rear axle

we should more than make up with vehicle
handling.

I can't wait to see how this thing
drives.
While we recorded peaks of 279 horsepower and 295 pound-feet of torque

we were happy to see torque stayed
above 290 for 4 out of the 5
runs varying around 5 feet.

Look at the shape of the power curve
how quickly

torque increases and how the curve falls
at 5300 rpm
that means the engine should feel great in the lower midrange giving
tons of torque but might feel soft when you rev it out. Surprised by the
lack of high rpm
grunt? You shouldn't be look at the power torque graph of the Ford Fiesta ST
and you'll see a very similar shape though at lower numbers.
Clearly this engine was developed with similar mindset and well
we love that Fiesta.

With stability control off on the car and
track mode

a launch involved holding both pedals
waiting for boost to surge.
It's an amusing process. Thru the quarter at 14.1 seconds
at 97.8 miles an hour the Ecoboost falls

right between the best time reported
from the Hyundai Genesis Coupe
and the Volkswagen GTI.

25.5 seconds figure-8 lap matches
that of the Subaru WRX and Genesis Coupe
as does its 0.96 average level g
it also falls right around the last gen automatic Mustang V6 performance
in all tests.
The Mustang Ecoboost is one of the cars have been most interested in driving this year
because its a turbo four-cylinder Mustang.
We haven't had that since around the time I was born.

How is it well interesting because
you're expecting this to be a
replacement for the V8

or a competitive alternative it's not in
terms of power delivery
and fun factor but is a significant

upgrade over the V6. The steering I
actually like
quite a bit in precision and
waiting too you turn the wheel the car goes and there's not a lot of fuss or fake
stuff happening in between that process it feels natural no matter what.

The motor is all low RPMs all mid-range as
we found on the dyno
and that's something we notice when you push this car
trying to bring out every last RPM you find out that the power band
gets above 55 RPM it
gets louder but they're not necessarily
going faster and short shifting
that works that's something you have to do in these mid-range engines
although revving out engines is a lot more fun.
I think my excitement

of this car comes from the fact that I
remember what the base
v6 Mustang was like even the V6 premium they

started recently and the performance
package they threw on that.

There was a better that but this is such
a better car.

Now the problems there are many I think
the biggest issue that's facing this
car is
weight. This thing is just over 3600 pounds
and when you have 310 horsepower

that's a power to weight ratio in the
11s which

isn't that great you know this thing
may have a higher specific power output
than most thirty thousand dollars sporty cars
but that weight will hold it back.

I think what we have here isn't so much
the second coming of the turbo
performance Mustang but a much better

realistic Mustang for most people to
drive around every day.
I quite like this car

tooling around town driving on the
freeway

the low RPM feels great it still
looks cool all the features are nice
to use and you know around of resting on a ramp that have

caused the change radii all that stuff
its fun.

Pushing it like him trying to upgrade
speaker start seeing the scene
but again at ok.
Streets of Willow and the Mustang EcoBoost.
Got a little 2.3 liter 4 with a turbo on it.

the body structure is one of the areas
where the Mustang is
way better than it was last year I can feel it.
I can feel it on the road and track.

Very strong body structure years with
suspension something better to hang on.

Alright this pony and this cowboy are
all warmed up

this time to turn the clocks on
see what kind of time we can run.
With the little EcoBoost 4 cylinder here at Willow Springs.

It may not be the performance-oriented
version we hoped
but makes a very pleasant non-V8 entry in the Mustang lineup

matching performance and price of
similar cars

provided you are being unreasonable it's
by no means a replacement for that V8
nor is it the penalty box the V6 used to be it's better than that car in
every way.
Plus it's higher fuel economy rating
and strong low RPM power delivery make a compelling choice as a daily driver.

title: 2015 Ford Mustang EcoBoost: SVO Reborn? - Ignition Ep. 117

comments.text:
It's just amazing how automotive technology has improved in such a short 
time. A V8 in a Mustang GT in 2003 had 260 hp and 302lb·ft of torque and 
that felt powerful. Back in 2007, the Mustang GT had 300 hp and 320lb·ft of 
torque. Now its 2015 and a 4 cyl Mustang has 310 hp and 320lb·ft of torque. 
Just think what it will be in another 10 years.﻿

comments.author: mylittleponydude

comments.text:
Its too bad, too bad, that all the hype 5 years ago was the "New Mustang" 
would appeal more to a European or "tuner" audience, and it would be 
smaller, lighter, and still come with the IRS.  Then they stuffed all that 
into the live axle, chucked it all out, and made it bigger and heavier than 
the S197.
What a shame really.  I can park my S197 next to a E36 M3, and the Mustang 
dominates the M3 like a sumo wrestler over a kick boxer.  Then you have a 
seat inside, and interior space is the same; open the trunk, and you'll fit 
just as many golf clubs in the M3.  It's all plastics and trim wasting 
space, and piling on the weight.
I really and truly had hopes for the new generation Mustang, especially 
with the new Eco-boost 3.7 available on many other Ford models.  It could 
have been Fords chance to enter a world of competition against other proper 
rear drive sports cars; and not just the long played out mind numbing 
battle of American Muscle.﻿

comments.author: hitek9wittafulclip

comments.text:
This is what I don't get about car "buff books" (MT, R&T, C&D, etc...)... I 
understand you're not a tuner magazine, but you guys should at least 
mention the aftermarket tuning potential of performance cars when you test 
them. It seems like you always approach car testing from a "Consumer 
Reports" point of view. You test cars like the only people who read/watch 
you guys are baby boomers who plan to buy (or more likely lease) a car for 
24 months, drive it around bone stock and then trade it in. I think you 
need to understand that many of your subscribers who buy performance 
vehicles modify them. If the plan is to lease the car for 24 months, you 
review here is spot on. If the plan is to buy the car, throw a few bolt-ons 
and a tune at it, you missed the point of this car. An enthusiast can buy 
an Ecoboost, throw a couple of grand at it and have a car that outperforms 
the GT and gets better fuel mileage for less money. Will it still be 
missing the V8 noise? Yes. Some of us actually prefer the sound of a turbo 
4 though. No, I'm not a kid with a fart-piped Civic. I'm 42 and own an Evo 
X with 400HP. I am this car's (and MT's) target demographic.﻿

comments.author: Dario “Dariush” Liotine

comments.text:
I have one and only one problem with the mustang ecoboost, and that is its 
weight.  One of the biggest advantages of a 4-cylinder over say a V8 is 
that it allows the car to be light on its feet, and at 3500 lbs, the 
4-cylinder mustang is anything but light.  Comparing it to say the FR-S, it 
has well over 700 lbs on the ecoboost (3526 v 2758).  Granted the ecoboost 
has a better power to weight ratio, from a cornering and braking 
perspective the FR-S should win, unless the FR-S's skinnier wheels make 
that big of a difference.﻿

comments.author: Sleekcartim .sleekcartim

comments.text:
I would imagine that Ford researched the market for this and it has some 
kind of future, but I don't care. While not the sheer apostasy of a Mustang 
II, it is an entirely mistaken concept. I don't really care for the 
perspective of the test, either. The entry level Mustang, formerly the 6 
cylinder, was not designed or sold as a track car, so why bother taking it 
to Willow Springs...3600 lbs. absurd weight, automatic (why even bother 
testing it with that transmission?)-I'm just vexed by the whole thing. Ford 
is playing other companies' game...I had a 2011 V6 with aftermarket 
exhaust. The car did everything I wanted out of it. 6 speed, good shift 
feel, it tore off the line and had real grunt that made me smile every 
time. It had a wonderful visceral quality that no one discusses in this 
review...the sound. Although it was not a V8, it sounded like an old Aston 
Martin race car or one of those ealy 70s Capri racers. A four cylinder will 
never make you feel that way. Even with the stupid limiter on the old 
Mustang, it was still great. I used it for exactly what I wanted out of 
it...not a track car, not a street racer, just something that looked great, 
sounded great every time I got into it. I looked at the GT and realized 
that it is just so hard to really use a car on public roads. If I really 
want to drive fast, I want something that is going to be more rewarding on 
the track. An independent rear suspension Boss 302 with some big brembos 
does sound fun, but that's another story. I think the 4 cylinder is fine 
for drivers who just want the look of the car, or Hertz. The 6 can give you 
something that is quite a bit more alive.
Beyond the motor, the car's lines are so unpleasantly Japanese...somehow 
reminiscent of a Celica now. Again, playing the game by other companies' 
rules...I would be much more interested in a BRZ, or a Hyundai Genesis 6 
cylinder than this sad iteration of a Mustang. It does not have to be 
archaic, but there was so much more room to flesh out the distinctive 
throwback looks. I could happily concede some style points for a flat crank 
V8 with this body, but that I4, 3600 lbs. and body together is just nothing 
I would spend money on. ﻿
comments.author: Robert Neville

comments.text:
I'm not a fan of the new "Import Styling" for the Mustang. It looks like a 
sick fusion between a bad attempt to rip-off Aston Martin and Jaguar, and 
someone's customized 2005 Hyundai Tiburon. A 4 cylinder version is just 
plain sacrilege. If they were going to do an Ecoboost variant, they should 
have used the 3.5 V6 from the Taurus Police interceptor. Or even a twin 
turbo on the 5.0. That would be something. But I know they were trying to 
appeal to a more "Global" market. Can a water buffalo pulled version be far 
behind?  ﻿

comments.text:
Can anyone tell me why some have the circle with the GT and 50y 
annerversery on the rear end and some just have the letters GT?﻿
comments.author: Fitness and health

comments.text:
Thank for the comment. I found out that the one with the incircled logo is 
a limitied edition which is only procued in 1964 copies. And yes, it has 
some of the features you mentioned + more. Hope you enjoy for Mustang, 
can't wait till it is for sale in Denmark!
comments.author: Fitness and health

comments.text:
The difference is a trim level. If you buy a gt with 50th anniversary 
package you get the fake gas cap that you mentioned, chrome accents around 
the tail lights and a chrome corral grill. I think there may be some 
differences on the interior I'm not sure. I bought the regular gt premium 
which I like more. It's just a matter of personal taste.
comments.author: ruby gt

comments.text: How much less does the V6 weigh  than the GT?﻿
comments.author: james hurlbut

comments.text:
If you noticed, the dyno sheet clearly showed that the hotter the car gets 
the less power it made. Dyno run #3 had 278 whp and by run #6 it went down 
to 256 whp. This car needs an intercooler ASAP. Carlos, during your test 
runs at the track, how high was the engine oil temp? and Did you guys 
suffer from engine LIMP mode during track testing? Am curious because I 
ordered a basic ecoboost (premium PCK has too much crap I really don't use 
and it weights about 200 Lbs more), Perfomance PCK, Recaro seats with A/T 
(I can't drive a M/T, am a L/S foot amputee) which am going to use on track 
days and down here in Puerto Rico its about 90 degs avery day and over 100 
degs at the track. My plan with this little Mustang (I prefer the Camaro 
1LE for the track but it only comes in M/T & the Camaro V6 is too heavy and 
do not come with any performance goodies) is to get it cool first, engine & 
tranny oil coolers, intercooler and them a bit of power down pipe, replace 
that HUGE resonator with something more efficient & custom tune. I really 
enjoy your videos. BTW the H2H between the Z06 & GTR-Nismos was awesome! 

Saludos, Fernando﻿

comments.author: Santa Baby

comments.text:
Funny enough, I read someone's opinion about how the Mustang name holds the 
4 cylinder back. And I agree. It's a very fun car, gets decent mileage, can 
have a completely different personality with a tune and yet the fact that 
it is a Mustang overshadows all of that. People expect to hear a deep V8 
growl not turbo spool and to get pushed back in their seat all the way up 
to redline. If this 2.3 was maybe a little lighter and thrown into another 
rwd (let's call it Maverick for nostalgia) I'm sure people would be 
praising it all day.﻿
comments.author: Chris Vela

comments.text: A Ford with 4 cylinder? What is this madness lol.﻿
comments.author: Ray Lee

comments.text:
This is a great move by Ford. V8s and V6s aren't really a viable option for 
Europeans due to high tax, petrol and narrow winding roads which is why the 
hot hatch rules. I'm seriously considering taking this for a test drive as 
the hot hatches are too common and pretty dull to look at these days. In 
the UK now there are many garages that do official remaps that don't void 
warranties. Plus I bet with some extra mods I could easily get this down to 
low 5sec time. Also I know a dealer that will sell this for less that 
£25k.. that's incredible performance for price.﻿
comments.author: mit
